section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we help animals stay healthy?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Anna McQuinn Illustrated by Rosalind Beardshaw
section-block.rac_book_summary: When Lola wants a cat, she learns all about how to care for one. After she gets her cat Makeda, she does everything she can to make Makeda happy, including reading aloud to her.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: discover animals | Week 2: Caring for Pets

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about how people adopt pets from animal shelters. These pets don’t have homes until they are adopted.
Invite children to pretend to be cats to build excitement for learning about caring for pets. Suggest children purr, arch their backs, curl up, and swish their tails.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Lola Gets a Cat, written by Anna McQuinn and illustrated by Rosalind Beardshaw.
Scout loves all books, but he especially loves narratives like this one. They tell such interesting stories!
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How can we help pets stay healthy?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look at all the cats on Lola’s bed. What do they look like? Are they different colors?
Look at what Lola is holding. What is she doing to help a cat stay healthy?
Why does Lola pretend Dinah is a real cat?
Look at what Lola and Mommy are doing. Where are they looking to find a shelter?
Look at the picture. What is the cat doing? How does the cat choose Lola?
Look at all the things Lola and Daddy put in Makeda’s special corner. What things in the corner will help Makeda stay healthy?
Do you think Lola knows how to take good care of her cat? How do you know?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How can we help pets stay healthy?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Then pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: We give them a place to live.
We can make sure they get regular exercise.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about caring for pets as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do all animals need food and water?
All animals need f______ (food) and water.
All animals need food and water.
What else can you do to help a pet stay healthy?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: According to researchers, reading picture books to children will help them build a richer vocabulary and understand the rules of grammar, which will in turn help them as they learn to read on their own.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Express Pride
section-block.rac_body-text: Start a discussion with children about something they can do that they feel proud of, or pleased about. They might name dancing, singing a song, catching a ball, or something else new that they learned. Explain that when we achieve something we feel good about, we can talk about it to other people.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to look for the express pride Mind Builder as we revisit the book Lola Gets a Cat, written by Anna McQuinn and illustrated by Rosalind Beardshaw.
This story is about a girl who gets a cat as a pet. Clifford loves narratives about pets because he is a pet, too!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and talk about some of the pages in the story to focus on the express pride Mind Builder.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is Lola doing on these pages that she can feel proud of? (MB)
What face would you make if you were proud of something you did? (MB)
How does Lola pretend to care for Dinah?
What are some things you care for? How do you feel about caring for them? (MB)
Look at the special corner Lola and her father made. How does Lola show that she feels proud of it? (MB)
Look at what Lola is checking off on her chart. What does she do for her cat?
Look at Makeda snuggle Lola on her bed. Does Makeda still look afraid? Did Lola do a good job to help Makeda feel at home?

section.rac_body-text: Challenge children to express pride by pretending to do things that they are proud they can do. Invite them to get in a circle and take turns naming and showing what they can do. For example, one child might say, “I can throw,” and pretend to be throwing a ball. Another child might say, “I can walk a dog,” and act that out. After one child takes a turn, have him or her choose the next child to take a turn.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about expressing pride at what they can do.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children’s understanding of what they can do is an important part of their emotional development because it indicates that they have a growing self-awareness. When children begin to feel and express pride about what they can do, it helps them to feel more positive about themselves. (Morgan, 2015).

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about asking and answering questions when they listen to stories.
Sing “Where is (Name)?” to the tune of “Frèrè Jacques.” All: “Where is (Name)?” (repeat) Child: “Here I am.” (repeat) All: “How are you today?” (repeat) Child: “I am fine.” (repeat)

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Lola Gets a Cat, written by Anna McQuinn and illustrated by Rosalind Beardshaw.
Scout loves Lola Gets a Cat because Lola learns how to do something new. Scout loves narratives about characters who learn!
This is the question I want you to think about as we read:
What does Lola’s new pet, Makeda, need?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions. Encourage children to provide extended responses as appropriate.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does Lola do when she pretends that Dinah is a real cat?
Why do Lola and Mommy need to go shopping?
Why do you think the cat is scared? What will help the cat feel safe?
Look at Ty and Lola play with Makeda. Does Makeda still look scared? How can you tell?
What happens every evening? Do you think Makeda likes her new home?
Can you think of something you do every evening?
Did you ask and answer questions as we read the story today? Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What does Lola’s new pet, Makeda, need?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to choose 2–3 children to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Makeda needs a place to sleep.

section.rac_body-text: Work with children to write about pets. Ask each child to say the name of an animal they would like as a pet. Write the name of the animal, and then have the child write the name of the animal or draw a picture of it. Model writing a sentence that uses a personal pronoun and names the animal. For instance: I want a pet giraffe.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How can Lola help Makeda feel safe?

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: Asking and Answering Questions About a Story
section-block.rac_child_development_body: When children listen to a teacher read a story aloud, they have the opportunity to answer and ask questions about the book, which helps them become engaged in reading and making meaning. Discussing stories will also help children’s cognitive development.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: discover animals | Week 2: Caring for Pets

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to discuss what animals need. Encourage them to suggest how people can help animals stay healthy.
Invite children to sing about what pets need to the tune of “Mary Had a Little Lamb,” using their names instead of Mary’s and using different animals instead of a lamb.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read What Pets Need. It is an informational text in the form of a poster.
Scout loves posters, especially informational ones. They help Scout learn about new things!
Lola Gets a Cat and What Pets Need focus on what pets need to stay healthy. Let’s see if we find connections between the two!
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show the Lola Gets a Cat book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s Concept Question:
What do animals need to stay healthy?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Caring for Pets
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the Teacher Text on the Big Chart, then use these prompts to read and discuss the child-facing poster together.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to take turns responding.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: All pets need a safe home. Who can come point to their favorite pet?
Who can come point to the boy feeding his pet bird?
The girl is giving her dog a bath. Why is cleaning a pet important?
Who can come point to the pet that is getting exercise? In Lola Gets a Cat, how does Makeda get exercise?
Look at all the children caring for their pets and giving their pets love and affection. Why is giving a pet love important?

section.rac_body-text: Have children draw or create items that are useful for keeping pets healthy. Place items on a shelf so that it’s set up as a pet store. Some children can pretend to work at the store, while others pretend to shop for their pets.
Provide a writing prompt about caring for pets and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Playing can help children make a connection between a topic and what they are physically doing in the classroom. Play can also help children build reading and writing skills.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Discover Animals | Week 2: Caring for Pets

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to describe and act out what people need to do to care for their pets, such as giving them food, water, and love. Children can take turns being the person who cares for the pets or being the pets themselves.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book Lola Gets a Cat , written by Anna McQuinn and illustrated by Rosalind Beardshaw.
This book is a narrative, which means that it tells a story. Scout loves to hear and read stories!

This week we read all about Lola and how she learns what a cat needs to stay healthy. She wants to learn how to take care of her own cat. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: If you were a cat, what would you need to stay healthy?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does Lola do to find out about cats? Tell me what you would do to find out about cats.
How does Lola get ready to have a cat? What would you do to get ready for a cat?
How does the little cat act when she comes out of her carrier? How would you act in a new place?
What does Lola do to remember to give Makeda food and fresh water? What would you do to make sure you remember?
What does Lola’s friend Ty do with the string? How is he moving it? Pretend you are holding a piece of string and playing with a cat.
Why do you think snuggling Lola is Makeda’s favorite thing? Show me how Makeda snuggles.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: If you were a cat, what would you need to stay healthy?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
Invite children to draw or write about caring for pets and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do cats need fresh water to stay healthy?
Cats need fr________ (fresh) water to stay healthy.
Cats need fresh water to stay healthy.
What are some other things a cat would need to stay healthy?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Invite multilingual learners to listen to the reading and retelling of the book. Then, encourage them to speak to others who have the same first language.
